awd_titl_txt: A Novel Approach to Multistage Decision Making under Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
Management in most practical settings involves a series of decisions that must be made repeatedly under uncertainty over a long period of time. Many of these decisions involve yes/no decisions, as well as decisions regarding appropriate levels of various factors. For many such problems, stochastic mixed-integer programming (SMIP) provides a powerful modeling framework. Unfortunately, state-of-the-art SMIP algorithms cannot solve realistic-sized problems that arise in real-world contexts. This award supports fundamental research aimed at investigating novel approaches that can form a framework for a general-purpose multistage SMIP solver.  The broader impacts of this work will be felt in multiple domains. Should this approach prove successful, a much richer set of models can be solved in a variety of applications arising in healthcare, energy, manufacturing, and so on. The educational impacts will be felt by graduate and undergraduate students.

In this research, which is known as scenario-tree decomposition, a novel method will be developed for decomposing the scenario tree of a multistage SMIP, rather than its extensive form. One major advantage of such approach is that it will not require any particular structure. Based on preliminary results and prior work on establishing bounds for two-stage SMIPs, it will be shown that cuts of the scenario tree can generate lower and upper bounds on a multistage SMIP. Moreover, it is hypothesized that a hierarchy among such bounds can be established. These bounds will be incorporated into a global branch-and-bound framework. Furthermore, this approach may be generalized beyond the standard stochastic programming paradigm. For example, it may be amenable to certain classes of nonlinear SMIPs. This method is highly amenable to high-performance computing, and will provide users with an explicit tradeoff between the quality of the bounds and the requisite computational effort.

por.por_cntn:
Mixed-integer programs are ubiquitous across all industries. Large instances are routinely solved to model decisions arising in healthcare, energy, logistics, manufacturing, finance, and many others.  Mixed-integer programming is one of the major successes of operations research. These models are deterministic (the parameters are known with certainty) and take place in a single time period.

However, many practical decisions take place over many time periods under uncertainty, and involve yes/no decisions. Such problems are naturally modeled as stochastic mixed-integer programs. Unfortunately, unlike their deterministic counterparts, these models are extremely challenging to solve, as they lack many mathematical properties for algorithms to exploit. Faced with this challenge, this award develops methods for finding approximate solutions to these models. These solutions have several enviable properties: they provide lower and upper bounds, and these bounds are improved as the computational effort increases. They rely on no special structure, other than the natural structure inherent to multi-stage stochastic mixed-integer programs. Moreover, these solutions are highly parallelizable. These methods solve smaller, more manageable stochastic mixed-integer programs and then piece together their solutions to create estimates of the optimal value of the original, more difficult problem.

A related line of inquiry is to understand how to exploit the structure of a stochastic mixed-integer program when it exists. This award has supported several such inquiries. One is to characterize when multi-stage stochastic mixed-integer programs can be solved as much easier multi-stage stochastic linear programs. The latter models enjoy much structure, such as convexity of the expected recourse functions. Another important class of stochastic mixed-integer programs occurs when the constraint matrices are deterministic (fixed). For the two-stage versions of such problems, this award has supported the development of approach that is based on the generalized value function of a mixed-integer program, a heretofore unexplored parameterization of any mixed-integer program. 

This award has also supported research into related questions, such as inverse optimization and assessing families of integer programs. An inverse optimization problem is given the optimal solution, and determines which objectives might have yielded that solution in a classical ("forward") optimization problem. For these problems the award has supported research to understand the polyhedral structure of inverse linear programs, as well as the fundamental properties of inverse mixed-integer programs.

One key tool to many of these questions has been the superadditive dual of an integer program. Using this dual, this award has supported a novel method for comparing integer programming models over many right-hand sides.

The broader impacts of this award are felt wherever decisions must be made under uncertainty, including healthcare, energy, manufacturing, and other important sectors of the economy. This award has supported one PhD student who is already an independent researcher, and another who is expected to become an independent researcher by the Fall of 2019.

Modified by: Andrew Schaefer
